official-title.#text: To provide for scientific frameworks with respect to vector-borne diseases.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Subpart 6 of part C of title IV of the Public Health Service Act

header.#text: Development of Scientific Framework for Vector-Borne Diseases

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, the Directors shall develop a
			 scientific framework for the conduct or support of research on such
			 vector-borne disease.

text.#text: For each vector-borne disease identified under
The scientific framework with respect to a vector-borne disease shall include the following:
the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of acute and chronic vector-borne disease;

the fundamental environmental and biologic process that regulate acute and chronic vector-borne
			 disease; and
the epidemiology of acute and chronic vector-borne disease.
A summary of findings from the current literature in the areas of—
An assessment of the incidence of acute and chronic vector-borne disease reported internationally.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and

			 areas described in

develop a scientific framework under this subsection not later than 18 months after the date of the

review and update the scientific framework not later than 5 years after its initial development.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the Directors shall—

text.#text: For each vector-borne disease identified under

The Directors may review and update each scientific framework developed under this subsection as
			 necessary.

With respect to each scientific framework developed under this subsection, not later than 30 days
			 after the date of completion of the framework, the Directors shall—

make such framework publicly available on the Internet Web site of the Department of Health and

Not later than 6 months after the date of the enactment of this section, the Directors shall
			 identify 2 or more bacterial or parasitic vector-borne diseases that each
			 have a high incidence domestically.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, tick-borne diseases,
			 including Lyme disease and other tick-borne diseases that are known to be
			 transmitted by ticks to humans in the United States, shall be treated as a
			 single vector-borne disease.

text.#text:
For purposes of identifying vector-borne diseases under this subsection and developing scientific
			 frameworks for such diseases under

header.#text: Treating tick-borne diseases as a single vector-borne disease

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, the Directors may, at any time, identify other vector-borne diseases for
			 purposes of this section. In identifying a vector-borne disease pursuant
			 to the previous sentence, the Directors may consider additional metrics of
			 progress against such type of vector-borne disease.

text.#text: Subject to

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, the Directors shall convene a
			 working group in accordance with the

. The
			 Directors (or their designees) shall participate in the meetings of each
			 such working group.

text.#text: For each vector-borne disease identified under
Each working group convened under this subsection shall be comprised of the following members:
One or more representatives of each of the following:
The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, as determined appropriate
			 by the Directors.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Department of Health and Human Services

text.#text: Other agencies or offices of the
Other Federal agencies, as determined appropriate by the Directors.
One or more representatives of each of the following categories:

Physicians with experience in diagnosing and treating stages or manifestations of the relevant
			 vector-borne disease.

Non-Federal scientists or researchers with expertise, and representing a diversity of perspectives,
			 regarding the science pertaining to vector-borne diseases.
Patients and their family members.
Nonprofit organizations that advocate for patients by promoting education, services, or research.

Other individuals whose expertise is determined by the Directors to be beneficial to the
			 functioning of the working group.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Speaker of the House of Representatives

One individual appointed by the

short-title.#tail:
, any such working group is deemed to be an advisory committee subject to the Federal Advisory

text.#text:
If the Directors, in addition to convening the working groups required by this subsection, choose

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:

text.#text: The Directors shall, within 60 days after identifying a vector-borne disease under

to identify, and seek public input on, potential emerging strains in species of pathogenic
			 organisms.

The participants at the forums convened under this subsection shall be researchers, physicians,
			 patients, and other members of the public.

means an infection transmitted to humans or other animals by ticks, mosquitoes, or fleas, such as
